    • Method Detail

      • onCreate

        public void onCreate(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db)
        Called automatically when a database is being accessed while database does not exist. Takes a SQLiteDatabase to represent the Phone-side database class to write with. Creates a new empty database for user.
        Specified by:
        onCreate in class android.database.sqlite.SQLiteOpenHelper
        Parameters:
        db - The SQLiteDatabase to be constructed. Has no meaningful purpose since there is only ever one database

      • onUpgrade

        public void onUpgrade(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                      int oldVersion,
                      int newVersion)
        precondition: database was changed, we are upgrading to a new database. postcondition: new database created, all existing data lost. here we could do specific logic to transfer data from old database to new database.
        Specified by:
        onUpgrade in class android.database.sqlite.SQLiteOpenHelper
        Parameters:
        db - the phone database used to hold table
        oldVersion - the old version the database exists at
        newVersion - the new version to update the database to

      • getCalendarDetails

        public java.lang.String getCalendarDetails(java.lang.Long timeInMilliseconds)
        precondition: database already instantiated. postcondition: if readable database was not accessible, it is now accessible. After (re)building readable database access, queries CalendarEventTable to see if it contains details for supplied day of the week
        Parameters:
        timeInMilliseconds - the millisecond time representation of the given day. Fetchable by CalendarView.getDate() or through a Date object
        Returns:
        String containing Details message. Empty string if database query failed or no matching row

      • getCalendarEvent

        public eecs448_first_team.calender_app.CalendarEventDb.CalendarEvent getCalendarEvent(java.lang.Long timeInMilliseconds)
        precondition: database already instantiated. postcondition: if readable database was not accessible, it is now accessible. After (re)building readable database access, queries CalendarEventTable for a particular CalendarEvent
        Parameters:
        timeInMilliseconds - the millisecond time representation of the given day. Fetchable by CalendarView.getDate() or through a Date object
        Returns:
        a CalendarEvent object with a Day, an ID, and some Details, or Null if object does not exist or table corrupted

      • setCalendarDetails

        public boolean setCalendarDetails(java.lang.Long timeInMilliseconds,
                                  java.lang.String detailsForDay)
        After (re)building writeable database access, inserts a new row into CalendarEventTable overwriting an existing row with the same Date and storing the provided Details.
        Parameters:
        timeInMilliseconds - the millisecond time representation of the given day. Fetchable by CalendarView.getDate() or through a Date object
        detailsForDay - the details to add for the given day, ie "I had to mine more gold, but my supply cap was very high."
        Returns:
        True if Details were added successfully, False if Details adding failed (possibly table corrupted)

      • onDowngrade

        public void onDowngrade(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                        int oldVersion,
                        int newVersion)
        precondition: user reverting to old database version. postcondition: new database created, all existing data lost. here we could implement a way to preserve new data when reverting to an old database version.
        Overrides:
        onDowngrade in class android.database.sqlite.SQLiteOpenHelper
        Parameters:
        db - the database physically on the phone associated with this application
        oldVersion - the previous database version integer
        newVersion - the new version integer to update the database to
